Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Alleged alternative protection options in Guyana
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Assumption of automatic citizenship and lack of section 97 analysis
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to assess discretionary nature of Guyanese citizenship and omission of section 97 analysis
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Well-founded fear of persecution in all countries of citizenship or potential citizenship
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Discretionary aspect of acquiring citizenship under Guyanese law
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Independent analysis required under section 97 for risks outside section 96
Crimes.Application_Factor: Marital rights as basis for citizenship claim
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Remitted for reconsideration by a differently constituted tribunal
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Misrepresentation regarding citizenship eligibility through false assumption

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee protection claim
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the tribunal erred in finding Mrs. Khan had citizenship rights in Guyana and adequately analyzed Mr. Khan's need for protection under section 97
Crimes.Outcome: Tribunal's decision quashed, case remitted for reconsideration
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Use of false passport to enter U.S.; subjective fear questioned due to prior non-claim in U.S.
Crimes.Evidence_Type: False travel document, marital-based citizenship claim
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Lack of state protection in Guyana and criminal acts there
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Assumption that Mrs. Khan could acquire citizenship and failure to analyze Mr. Khan’s risk under section 97
Crimes.Application_Error: Assumed control over citizenship acquisition and omitted section 97 analysis
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Well-founded fear of persecution requiring assessment in each relevant country
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Nature of criminal acts in Guyana and lack of prior refugee claim context
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Requirement for independent risk analysis under section 97 when section 96 does not apply
Crimes.Application_Factor: Entry using false documents and absence of prior protection claim
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Remitted for reconsideration by a differently constituted tribunal
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Use of false passport and misrepresentation in immigration process

Legal_Issue: Credibility findings, state protection analysis, procedural fairness
Outcome: Judicial review granted, case remanded for redetermination
Legal_Provision: Section 96 (Convention refugee), Section 97 (person in need of protection)
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Credibility, availability of state protection, procedural fairness
Application_Factor: Persecution in Bangladesh due to political opinion
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim dismissed initially, decision set aside on judicial review

Crimes.Crime_Name: Making False Statements under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of refugee claim decision
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in credibility assessment and consideration of evidence
Crimes.Governing_Law: Sections 96 and 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility finding due to inconsistent documents and implausible narrative
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Inconsistent identity documents, oral testimony
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of forced marriage and rape in Burundi
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of credible evidence and failure to establish identity
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to prove identity and provide consistent evidence
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness of the Board's credibility analysis
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Standard of reasonableness applied to administrative decision
Crimes.Application_Factor: Implausible claims and contradictions in testimony
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Inconsistent or unreliable identity documentation

Crimes.Crime_Name: Identity Fraud under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of refugee claim decision
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in credibility assessment and consideration of evidence
Crimes.Governing_Law: Sections 96 and 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility finding due to inconsistencies in testimony and documents
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Contradictory personal testimony, questionable identity papers
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Claim for refugee protection based on fear of persecution
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to establish identity and lack of credible evidence
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Judicial review before the Federal Court
Crimes.Application_Error: Inability to verify identity and provide reliable documentation
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Standard of reasonableness
Crimes.Application_Factor: Discrepancies in identity and background details
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Claim dismissed due to lack of credibility and unverified identity
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Suspicious or inconsistent identity documents

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of refugee protection claim
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in assessing credibility and evidence
Crimes.Governing_Law: Sections 96 and 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Adverse credibility finding due to narrative discrepancies and lack of knowledge
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Oral testimony, written statements, identity documents
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of forced marriage and rape in Burundi
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to establish identity and inconsistent testimony
Crimes.Application_Error: Providing false or misleading information in support of refugee claim
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to administrative decisions
Crimes.Application_Factor: Inconsistencies in narrative and lack of familiarity with claimed personal details
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Use of potentially fraudulent or unreliable documents

Legal_Issue: Credibility of applicant, state protection presumption, procedural fairness
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), sections related to refugee protection and credibility assessment
Credibility_Assessment: Findings based on inconsistencies in testimony and lack of corroborating evidence
Evidence_Type: Testimonial evidence, lack of documentary corroboration
Legal_Provision: Section 96, 97 IRPA; standard of patent unreasonableness
Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution due to perceived political opinion and alleged military mistreatment in Mexico
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to rebut presumption of state protection in Mexico, credibility concerns
Proceeding_Type: Refugee appeal before the Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), followed by application for judicial review
Decision_Maker: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Federal Court
Application_Error: Failure to provide sufficient corroborating evidence, inconsistent testimony
Legal_Standard: Patent unreasonableness for credibility findings; reasonableness simpliciter for state protection
Application_Factor: Perceived political opinion, past mistreatment by state actors
Decision_Outcome: Dismissal of refugee claim and judicial review
Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Federal Court of Canada

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to provide acceptable identity documentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Outcome: Board's decision overturned, case remanded for re-evaluation
Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Federal Courts Act
Decision_Outcome: Unreasonable decision, remanded to new Board member
Credibility: Minor inconsistencies in testimony deemed significant

Legal_Issue: Rejection based on minor testimonial inconsistencies
Outcome: Board's decision overturned, case referred back for reassessment
Credibility_Assessment: Minor inconsistencies, translation issues, but substantial corroborating details
Basis_of_Claim: Lack of Somali identity documents, use of fraudulent passports
Legal_Standard: Reasonable justification for lack of documentation

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of immigration inadmissibility decision
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the immigration officer's decision to deny permanent residence based on association with ELF was legally sound
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), paragraph 34(1)(f)
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review granted; decision set aside for redetermination
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer's reasoning found flawed due to inadequate definition of terrorism
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Internet-sourced definition of terrorism, association evidence
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Membership in Eritrean Liberation Front (ELF)
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to properly define 'terrorism' and overreach on family inadmissibility
Crimes.Application_Error: Improper assumption of inadmissibility based on familial association
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Legal interpretation of terrorist or subversive activity under IRPA
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Lack of evidence linking family members directly to ELF activities
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Interpretation and application of paragraph 34(1)(f)
Crimes.Application_Factor: Association with organization alleged to engage in terrorism
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Decision overturned, case remanded for redetermination

Crimes.Crime_Name: Section 87 non-disclosure application delays and over-assertion of secrecy
Crimes.Violation_Type: Procedural delay and excessive secrecy claims
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 87 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Section 87
Crimes.Application_Facts: Delayed section 87 application and rescheduling of proceedings
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Eritrean refugees applying for permanent residence
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Delay in filing section 87 application and overbroad secrecy assertions by CSIS
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of transparency due to excessive secrecy
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Concerns about balance between national security and fairness
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Procedural flaws identified; recommendations for improvement
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review granted on other grounds; case remanded
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Fair and timely processing of permanent residence application
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Fairness and timeliness in non-disclosure processes
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Delays and over-assertion of secrecy undermined procedural fairness

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility due to association with terrorist or subversive activities
Crimes.National_Security_Element: Alleged membership in a terrorist organization (ELF)
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Potential risk from association with group engaging in subversive activities
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Based on past affiliation without individualized risk analysis
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Terrorist or subversive activities as defined under IRPA
Crimes.Leadership_Role: No indication of leadership role specified
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Officer relied on internet search, not authoritative sources
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Internet-based definition, organizational records
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer's interpretation deemed unreasonable
Crimes.Credibility_Factors: Lack of proper legal foundation for defining terrorism
Crimes.Standard_of_Proof: Balance of probabilities in administrative immigration context
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Inadmissibility challenge based on association
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Initial denial of permanent residence; later set aside for redetermination

Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Legal_Framework: International human rights law, Refugee law
Decision_Outcome: Board's decision found unreasonable and set aside
Institutional_Action: Rehearing ordered by a different member of the Board
Credibility: Evidence provided was credible and corroborated
State_Protection_Adequacy: State protection deemed inadequate due to police disinterest and hostility
Risk_Nature: Serious harm including physical attacks and systemic discrimination
Perpetrator_Entity: Private individuals, lack of state intervention
Victim_Basis: Membership in a particular social group (homosexuals)

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Does the applicant meet the tripartite test for a stay of removal: serious issue, irreparable harm, and balance of convenience?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s. 48(2)
Crimes.Outcome: Stay granted until humanitarian and compassionate application resolved
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of returning to St. Lucia due to domestic abuse and lack of support for children's medical needs
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Best interests of children, state protection, risk from ex-partner
Crimes.Application_Error: Officer failed to consider best interests of children and available state protection
Evidence_Ignored: Available state protection in St. Lucia
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Tripartite test: serious issue, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Misrepresentation in border documents

Crimes.Violation_Type: Overstay of authorized period of stay
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA sections related to temporary resident status
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa, has pending H&C application, fears domestic abuse in St. Lucia
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Failure to consider all relevant factors in deferral decision
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer focused only on practicality, ignored child welfare and risks
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Permission to remain in Canada during H&C processing
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness under IRPA, tripartite test for stay
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Serious issue, irreparable harm to children, balance of convenience favors applicant

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with removal order
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA sections on removal orders and compliance
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant remained in Canada after removal order due to fear of domestic violence and lack of state protection
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Removed person who failed to depart
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Best interests of children and risks in St. Lucia not considered
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Remain in Canada until H&C decision
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard, tripartite test for stay
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Applicant meets all three branches of the stay test

Crimes.Violation_Type: Actions placing children at risk upon removal
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA considerations regarding best interests of children
Crimes.Application_Facts: Removal would expose children to risks due to domestic violence, medical needs, and separation
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Irregular status due to pending proceedings
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Failure to assess child protection concerns in removal decision
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Best interests of children ignored by officer
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Protection for children from harm due to removal
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Tripartite test for stay of removal
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Risk of irreparable harm to children if removed

Crimes.Criminality_Severity: High – ongoing threat to life and safety
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High risk of harm upon return
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Yes – specific threats from known individual
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant found credible
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Considered under IRPA s. 117(9) for H&C grounds

Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, S.C. 2001, c. 27
Credibility_Assessment: Doubted identity and conversion due to inconsistent testimony and document conditions
Legal_Provision: Assessment of credibility based on documentation or reasonable explanations for absence
Basis_of_Claim: Conversion to Christianity, fear of persecution
Assessment_Standard: Reasonable possibility of persecution supported by credible evidence
Evidence_Ignored: No proof that documents were fake

Crimes.Crime_Name: Making a misrepresentation to obtain immigration benefits

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Interference of persuasive Board decisions with member's discretion
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claim found to be economically motivated, not based on credible fear of persecution
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Economic motivation outweighed claims of persecution
Crimes.Application_Error: Misrepresentation through omission or false emphasis
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Correctness standard for procedural fairness
Crimes.Application_Factor: Intent to remain permanently despite claims of fear
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Correctness for procedural fairness, reasonableness for factual findings

Crimes.Crime_Name: False statements in an immigration application
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration and Refugee Protection
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Interference of persuasive Board decisions with member's discretion
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review dismissed, no question certified
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Lack of credible fear; inconsistent intent to return to Mexico
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Inconsistent statements about return to Mexico
Crimes.Application_Error: False statements regarding intent and fear of return
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Credibility assessment based on consistency and plausibility
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Correctness for procedural fairness
Crimes.Application_Factor: Pattern of implausible claims and return intentions
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Correctness for procedural fairness, reasonableness for credibility findings

Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Dispute_Type: Allegation of bias against a decision-maker due to past national affiliations
Legal_Provision_Involved: Objective test for reasonable apprehension of bias
Grounds_for_Claim: Panel member's historical connections with Israel
Decision_Outcome: No legal error found; recusal motion properly assessed
Risk_Factor: Perceived lack of impartiality due to prior national ties
Credibility: Panel member's demonstrated impartiality over time and in past decisions
Legal_Provision: Principle of objective appearance of impartiality in administrative and judicial decision-making
State_Protection_Adequacy: Adequate, as proper legal test was applied and upheld on review
Risk_Nature: Procedural fairness and perception of bias
Perpetrator_Entity: Panel member (Mr. La Salle) accused of bias
Victim_Basis: Claimant before the panel alleging unfair treatment

Sentencing_Issue: Government withdrawal of clemency support impacted individual's right to procedural fairness

Application_Facts: Applicant spent significant time abroad and lacked clear evidence of maintaining a Canadian residence
Residency_Compliance: Failed to meet 1,095-day residency requirement within four years preceding application
Procedural_Issue: Unclear reasoning by Citizenship Judge, failure to resolve ambiguities in 'information on file' notes
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of clear documentation showing maintained Canadian residence
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration by a new Citizenship Judge
Legal_Standard_Applied: 1,095 days of physical presence required; exceptions for special circumstances under Federal Court jurisprudence
Decision_Rationale: Insufficient reasoning and unresolved factual ambiguities rendered the decision unreasonable

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 183 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRPR)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Mr. Sodhi overstayed his visa, left Canada, and reapplied for a student visa; evidence showed attendance at Algonquin College after departure date.
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Not applicable – decision based on non-compliance, not false information
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Alleged lack of procedural fairness in refusal
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal court jurisdiction over immigration decisions
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No proof of studies in India during gap period
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer questioned credibility due to academic attendance in Canada post-departure
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Certification of general importance and quashing of refusal
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of visa officer’s decision
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer reasonably concluded re-entry without authorization based on applicant-provided evidence

Crimes.Crime_Name: Re-entering Canada without authorization under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration admissibility
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether Mr. Sodhi re-entered Canada illegally after deportation
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Transcripts and diploma indicated Canadian study post-2005 without valid status
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate lawful entry and compliance
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Lack of documentation supporting studies in India or lawful re-entry
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Applicants must prove they entered Canada legally and will comply with visa terms
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged error in factual findings and procedural unfairness
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA sections related to admissibility and visa issuance
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Visa officer relied on applicant-submitted documents
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence (transcripts, diploma)

Crimes.Application_Facts: Mr. Sodhi did not provide evidence of lawful status or explain presence in Canada after departure
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Deported individual reapplying for student visa
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: History of non-compliance with immigration status
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Implied omission of whereabouts and re-entry details
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Allegation that officer failed to give chance to respond to adverse inference
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Student transcripts, diploma, absence of Indian study records
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No documentation proving legal stay outside Canada or authorized re-entry
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer found applicant's explanation insufficient
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Visa refused due to credibility and compliance concerns
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: All evidence was provided by applicant; no procedural unfairness found

Violation_Type: Failure to meet physical residence requirement
Application_Facts: Appellants were present in Canada for only 111 days and absent for 1,112 days in the four years preceding their citizenship application; their mode of living was centered in Hong Kong, including leasing an apartment and schooling their child there.
Procedural_Issue: Delayed notification under legitimate expectation doctrine raised but not upheld
Evidence_Used: Records of physical presence/absence, lease agreements in Hong Kong, school enrollment of child in Hong Kong
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence of physical presence in Canada
Remedy_Sought: Appeal to Federal Court to overturn refusal of citizenship application
Legal_Standard_Applied: Requirement of 1,095 days of physical presence in Canada under s. 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Decision_Rationale: Appellants did not meet the minimum physical residence requirement; central mode of living remained outside Canada

Legal_Issue: Did the Appeal Board err in failing to place Rosemary Haney on the eligibility list after finding her qualified?
Evidence_Assessment: Eligibility list expiration, pass mark validity, candidate qualifications
Burden_of_Proof: On applicants to demonstrate error in selection process
Credibility_Factor: Perceived bias and procedural irregularities in selection process
Legal_Rule: Commission must select highest-ranking qualified candidates for eligibility lists under s. 17(1)
Grounds_for_Claim: Procedural errors, improper application of pass mark, failure to update eligibility list
Outcome_on_Merits: Appeal Board erred in narrow interpretation of jurisdiction
Key_Evidence_Considered: Revised pass mark rendering Haney qualified, expired eligibility list
Legal_Framework: Public Service Employment Act, administrative law principles
Defendant_Response: Appeal Board cited expired list and limited jurisdiction
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review, correction of eligibility list
Outcome: Judicial review granted, case remanded to new Appeal Board
Legal_Provision: s. 17(1) of the Public Service Employment Act
Authority: Federal Court or equivalent reviewing tribunal

Violation_Type: Lack of credible evidence of persecution
Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 97 (Person in need of protection) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Applicants claimed fear of persecution in Zimbabwe due to perceived political opinions
Wife and child dependent on principal applicant's claim
Residency_Compliance: Traveled freely in Zimbabwe without state interference
Procedural_Issue: Reliance on principal applicant’s claim without independent evidence from family members
Evidentiary_Deficiency: No credible or corroborative evidence of persecution
Insufficient individual claims by spouse and child
Credibility_Assessment: Board found applicants' fear of persecution not credible
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim rejected by Refugee Protection Division
Relief_Sought: Recognition as Convention refugees or persons in need of protection
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of Refugee Protection Division decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution on Convention grounds
Decision_Rationale: No objective basis for fear of persecution
Inconsistent behavior with claimed fear (e.g., travel)

Violation_Type: Denial of deferral request for removal
Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 48 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Applicant requested deferral due to pregnant wife's medical complications
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence that applicant was essential for care
Decision_Rationale: No live controversy remains; decision within acceptable range of outcomes

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of immigration inadmissibility decision
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Visa Officer erred in finding misrepresentation under s. 40(1)(a)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's inconsistent statements and lack of credible documentation raised concerns about credibility
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Inconsistent information on employment history, work experience, job offers, and supporting documents
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 40(1)(a) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Material misrepresentation regarding employment and job offers
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Inconsistencies in employment details and lack of verifiable documentation
Crimes.Application_Error: Provided false or inconsistent information in application
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness of the Visa Officer's decision
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Misrepresentation that induces or could induce an error in administering the Act
Crimes.Application_Factor: Language proficiency, arranged employment, procedural fairness, misrepresentation
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: No breach of procedural fairness; decision upheld
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Alleged inconsistencies suggesting potential falsification of employment records

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility to Canada under s. 40(1)(a) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 40(1)(a) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Inconsistent claims about employment history, job offers, and professional experience by Ms. Bellido
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: N/A – application denied prior to residency grant
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: False statements regarding work experience and job connections
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Alleged lack of procedural fairness – found not applicable
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over visa officer’s decision
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Application forms, supporting documents, discrepancies identified by Visa Officer
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of credible and consistent documentation supporting employment claims
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility due to material inconsistencies
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review allowing the application to proceed
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Misrepresentation that induces or could induce error in administration of the Act
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Visa Officer reasonably concluded material facts were misrepresented
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Visa Officer and Federal Court on review

Violation_Type: Failure to maintain permanent resident status
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s.49(1)
Application_Facts: Applicant's appeal against removal order was ongoing; removal order not yet in effect; applicant failed to meet residency obligations
Residency_Compliance: No – failed to meet residency obligations
Procedural_Issue: No delay allowed under Citizenship Act s.14(1); citizenship application reviewed during pending removal appeal
Outcome: Appeal dismissed; citizenship judge's decision upheld
Remedy_Sought: Reapplication permitted upon successful appeal of removal order
Legal_Standard_Applied: Eligibility under Citizenship Act s.5(1)(c) and (f)
Decision_Rationale: Applicant ineligible due to being under a removal order despite retaining permanent resident status during appeal

Application_Facts: Applicant was physically present for 691 days; maintained strong ties to Canada including family, property, and frequent returns
Residency_Compliance: No – fell short of 1,095-day requirement; central mode of existence disputed
Procedural_Issue: Misapplication of the Re Koo centralized mode of existence test; factual errors by Citizenship Judge
Evidence_Used: Physical presence records, family ties, property ownership, travel history
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient assessment of comparative ties to Canada vs. other countries
Outcome: Case remanded to another Citizenship Judge for re-determination
Remedy_Sought: Reassessment of residency based on proper application of law and facts
Legal_Standard_Applied: Centralized mode of existence test from Re Koo
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness for factual and legal issues; correctness for procedural fairness
Decision_Rationale: Significant factual errors and misapplication of the Re Koo test in assessing residency
Authority_Responsible: Citizenship Judge, Federal Court (on judicial review)

Violation_Type: Failure to apply correct legal test for state protection
Legal_Provision_Violated: Presumption of state protection under the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), sections related to refugee protection and burden of proof
Application_Facts: Hungarian Roma family claimed refugee status due to systemic discrimination and lack of effective state protection in Hungary
Claimant_Status: Roma family from Hungary seeking refugee protection
Procedural_Issue: Inconsistent application of legal standard; Board initially stated correct standard but applied a lower threshold ('somewhat rebut')
Evidence_Used: Evidence of discrimination against Roma community in Hungary, claims of inadequate state response
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to meet clear and convincing evidence standard to rebut presumption of state protection
Decision_Outcome: Refugee status initially granted by Refugee Protection Division
Outcome: Judicial review allowed; decision set aside
Relief_Sought: Minister sought judicial review of RPD's grant of refugee status
Remedy_Sought: Remittal of the case for reconsideration by a different member
Legal_Standard_Applied: Balance of probabilities with requirement to provide clear and convincing evidence to rebut presumption of state protection
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness, correctness for questions of law
Decision_Rationale: Board failed to consistently apply the correct legal test, creating uncertainty in the decision-making process
Authority_Responsible: Refugee Protection Division (RPD), Immigration and Refugee Board

Risk_Assessment: High risk due to lack of credible rehabilitation
Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient evidence of non-compliance and reoffending

Prior_Criminality: Repeated criminal behavior despite previous leniency
Risk_Assessment: High risk due to pattern of criminal conduct

Crime_Name: Failure to comply with a court order
Application_Facts: Applicant failed to meet conditions during stay period
Credibility_Assessment: Lack of diligence in seeking assessment
Remedy_Sought: Stay of removal based on humanitarian grounds
Decision_Rationale: No procedural fairness breach; applicant not diligent

Credibility_Assessment: Applicant lacked diligence in obtaining assessment
Legal_Provision: Rule 48 of the Immigration Appeal Division Rules

Legal_Issue: Refusal to postpone hearing and factual conclusions
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show humanitarian grounds
Legal_Provision: Section related to humanitarian and compassionate grounds

Key_Evidence_Considered: Pattern of fraud, failure to comply with stay conditions
Defendant_Response: Sought delay to submit psycho-social assessment
Legal_Provision: Sections relating to H&C considerations and appeals

Dispute_Type: Complaint of racial discrimination in a federal workplace
Legal_Issue: Whether the Canadian Human Rights Commission reasonably applied s. 41(1)(a) of the Canadian Human Rights Act
Evidence_Assessment: Applicant was given 90 days by the Chief of Defence Staff to file a harassment complaint but did not do so
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to demonstrate that internal procedures were not reasonably available or that failure to use them was justified
Credibility_Factor: Commission found the applicant's failure to use the internal process was attributable to the applicant
Legal_Rule: Under s. 41(1)(a), the Commission may decline a complaint if other grievance procedures have not been exhausted
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged racial discrimination by the employer
Outcome_on_Merits: Not reached; complaint dismissed on procedural grounds
Key_Evidence_Considered: Existence and availability of the internal harassment complaint process, timeline provided by Chief of Defence Staff
Legal_Framework: Administrative law, human rights law, statutory interpretation
Defendant_Response: The Commission declined the complaint due to unexhausted internal procedures
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence of policy and directives, procedural timelines
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of the Commission’s decision to dismiss the complaint
Legal_Provision: s. 41(1)(a) of the Canadian Human Rights Act
Authority: Canadian Human Rights Commission, Federal Court

Application_Facts: Ghanuom family feared persecution in Lebanon and Israel based on past actions and affiliations
Procedural_Issue: Applicants claimed procedural unfairness due to the member forgetting notes
Evidence_Used: Decision dismissed claims of persecution as mere discrimination/harassment
Credibility_Assessment: Claims of persecution not meeting Convention standards
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed, no certification of general importance
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of Refugee Protection Division's dismissal
Legal_Standard_Applied: Procedural fairness requires a fair hearing
Reasonableness standard applies to administrative decisions
Decision_Rationale: No confusion was evident; persecution claims deemed as discrimination/harassment not rising to Convention level
